answers.answer: I don't know but that is a sign of early neuropathy.  Is the diabetes under control?

Um not sure, :s I can't find my meter, I know that bad.I'm gonna get another one next apptment.I lost alot of weight so I didn't think I still had diebetes ..when that happens what's that mean early nerapthy

You will get a better explanation on the Diabetes 2 forum and perhaps some help to get back on track.  Losing weight can be an indication of things going down hill as well as things going up hill.  Better to go by actual test results.  I would check out the forum.  Even if you don't post, just reading some other posts over the past months can really help.
i don't know anything about this sympton but please get it checked out.  good luck to you and keep us posted.  best wishes.  belle

Peripheral neuropathy is common in diabetics with poor blood control, Danni. You really need to consult with whoever is managing this, either your primary care guy or your endocrinologist. It can lead to permanent nerve damage and eventually loss of toes, limbs and the ability to walk. He/she can work with you to help you lower your blood sugar levels to reduce further damage. Have you ever been to a diabetes education class where they teach you about diet and exercise etc?Please don’t let this go, Danni.--Bill
I want to second Bill's recommendation.  I should have mentioned it in my post.  Time for a docs appt and the big test that all of us like to avoid:  the HbA1c.
PS I meant that all of us like to avoid when we are being bad with our diet :)

You can get a meter at any drug store for free with the purchase of 100 test strips.  Every drug store.You need to get a new meter yesterday.  How long has it been since you checked your sugar?  When was your last a1c?Comments above are correct.  Loss of weight can be DUE TO uncontrolled blood sugar.  You can lose a lot of weight fast.When you're getting that meter, get ketostix as well.  Check for ketones.  And make an appointment with your doctor/endo!

Yes, get checked right away and like suezeque said you need to check for ketones!!!www.ncbi.nlm.nih.govDiabetic ketoacidosis is a problem that occurs in people with diabetes. It occurs when the body cannot use sugar (glucose) as a fuel source because there is no insulin or not enough insulin. Fat is used for fuel instead....Also something to note if you have cirrhosis and an enlarged spleen: my a1c numbers tend to run lower than they should be as the test assumes an average life span of red blood cellsclinical.diabetesjournals.org/content/22/1/42.fullby M McNeely - 2004 - Cited by 4 - Related articlesAny condition that reduces erythrocyte survival, such as cirrhosis or hemolysis resulting from hypersplenism can cause spuriously low A1C levels.A fructosamine test will show you more accurate numbers although they don't go back as far as an a1c does.Diabetes can be a fully manageable condition, but man it can be frickin tough, especially around the holidays.And like Bill said, it is not just diet, exercise is soooo important.If you fall off, don't get discouraged, get back on and do it again.I say  this as much for my benefit as anyone else!We can't afford to wait until we are going blind and they start chopping off our body parts...Good luck and hang tough,Chris

Omg, seriously what is wrong with my head,I am not a stupid person I just make careless choices.Like I was saying to someone for along time I didn't care whether I lived or not.And for along time had this gaping hole inside me,that couldn't fill,almost like I'm disconected or just a being of loneliness .And felt this as a young child,and felt that I couldn't feel love,when it was shining on me...But ya long story short i still have the behaviors of a person who does care about herself,when actually I do care and want to get on top of things,I just feel emotionally tired,and feel so tired I forget stuff,like saying danni go find your meter,I did go to the doctors and she only deals with one problem at atime,so that leaves me having to go out again,I know it's terible ...but  I'm just tired ..
Fatigue and sleepiness is a strong sign of diabetes that is poorly controlled.
. . . along with mental changes such as confusion. . .

please, please, please get yourself to the doctor.  all of the above is correct.  you don't want to lose your body parts.  keep us posted.  and btw you're loved by all your cyber friends here.  good luck.  belle

I know what you're going through.Don't let that fact that your doctor will cr@p on you keep you from going!  Most people with diabetes know what they're supposed to do.  Intellectually it's a no-brainer.  Doing those things is what's hard!  So as the doctor says "You know better blahblahblah" just take it in and try not to be discouraged.It's NEVER too late to start taking care of yourself!

question: Over the last couple of weeks I've had pins and needles in my feet? Why is this happening?
title: Just weird
